[[Lee Mendelson]] | runtime = 50 minutes | company = | distributor = | channel = [[CBS]] | first_aired = January 29, 1988 | preceded_by = ''[[Happy New Year, Charlie Brown!]]'' | followed_by = ''[[It's the Girl in the Red Truck, Charlie Brown]]'' }} '''''Snoopy: The Musical''''' is the 31st [[prime-time]] [[animated]] [[TV special]]s, based on characters from the Charles M. Schulz [[comic strip]] ''[[Peanuts]]''. It is an adaptation of the [[musical theatre|musical]] [[Snoopy!!! The Musical|of the same name]], and originally aired on the [[CBS]] network in 1988. This is one of the two musicals in the ''Peanuts'' franchise where Snoopy actually has a voice (although the other kids can still not hear him). ==Plot== A series of vignettes are strung together regarding the ''Peanuts'' gang. Each vignette has a song that involves various members of the gang. * "Don't Be Anything Less Than Everything You Can Be" - Charlie Brown, Peppermint Patty, Sally and Linus sing about being the best that you can be, as Snoopy observes. * "Snoopy’s Song" - Snoopy decides to obey his owner more after Lucy almost convinces Charlie to trade him in for a cat. * "Woodstock's Theme" - More of a musical interlude than a vignette. A small musical selection plays as Woodstock wakes up and flies, with Snoopy commenting on his technique. * "Edgar Allan Poe" - Peppermint Patty, Lucy, Sally, Linus, Charlie Brown agonize over the teacher calling on them, figuring that no matter what, the teacher will ask them something having to do with [[Edgar Allan Poe]]. * "I Know Now" - Sally, Peppermint Patty and Lucy sing about what they have learned as they have grown up. * "The Vigil" - Linus once again holds vigil in the pumpkin patch on Halloween night, in hopes that the [[Great Pumpkin]] will appear. Snoopy accompanies him, but wears dark glasses so as to prevent anyone from recognizing him. * "Clouds" - The Peanuts gang lay about in a grassy meadow, talking about what they see in the clouds. (Basically a musical take on the opening scene from ''[[A Boy Named Charlie Brown]]''.) * "The Great Writer" - Snoopy attempts to compose his written masterpiece: "It Was a Dark and Stormy Night". * "Poor Sweet Baby" - Peppermint Patty and Charlie Brown discuss understanding what love is. * "The Big Bow-Wow" - Snoopy is selected as Head Beagle, and celebrates by going out on the town, and performing at a stage show. * "Just One Person" - The Peanuts gang sing an ensemble piece about believing in yourself ==Notes== * Having adapted the [[Musical theater|musical]] ''[[You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown]]'' three years prior, Charles Schulz once again opted to adapt the other musical with the ''Peanuts'' gang. Schulz had recently utilized many comic strips for ''[[The Charlie Brown and Snoopy Show]]''. * The song "Poor Sweet Baby" was based on the comic strip on 4/8/73 and the Broadway version song "Hurry up Face" was based on the comic strip on 9/17/72. * The idea of Lucy mistaking a potato chip for a butterfly was borrowed from 1969's ''[[It Was a Short Summer, Charlie Brown]]''. * Stock animation of the kids leaving the school in ''[[You're Not Elected Charlie Brown]]'' and ''[[Be My Valentine, Charlie Brown]]'' was used in the "Just One Person" number. * Stock animation of Sally leaving the school in ''[[You're Not Elected Charlie Brown]]'' was used for her entrance in the "Just One Person" number. * Stock animations of Charlie Brown kissing The Little Red-Haired Girl, flying and landing in his bed in ''[[It's Your First Kiss, Charlie Brown]]'' and Peppermint Patty and Charlie Brown talking under the tree in ''[[There's No Time for Love, Charlie Brown]]'' and ''[[It's Arbor Day, Charlie Brown]]'' were used for the "Poor Sweet Baby" segment. Plus the "Heather" version of The Little Red-Haired Girl makes a final cameo appearance. *Rerun makes a brief cameo in the song "I Know Now" after Linus upsets him and is confronted by their parents. *The Cat Next Door appears on screen for the first time. Here, it resembles Brutus from the 1977 film ''[[Race For Your Life, Charlie Brown]]''. *Constantly in the special, [[Lucy van Pelt|Lucy]] and [[Patricia "Peppermint Patty" Reichardt|Peppermint Patty]] switch voices. *This is the first time Snoopy was voiced by [[Cam Clarke|Cameron Clarke]], the second time was [[This is America, Charlie Brown]]. ==Cast== * Tiffany Billings as [[Lucy van Pelt]] (speaking/singing) * Kristie Baker as [[Peppermint Patty]] (speaking/singing) (credited as Kristi Baker) * [[Cam Clarke|Cameron Clarke]] as [[Snoopy]] (speaking/singing) * Sean Collins as [[Charlie Brown]] (speaking/singing) (credited as Sean Collins) * [[Ami Foster]] as [[Sally Brown]] (speaking/singing) * [[Jeremy Miller]] as [[Linus van Pelt]] (speaking/singing) * [[Bill Melendez]] as Snoopy (vocal effects) and [[Woodstock (Peanuts)|Woodstock]] (uncredited) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0174222|Snoopy!!! The Musical}} {{Peanuts television specials}} [[Category:Peanuts television specials]] [[Category:1988 television specials]] [[Category:1988 in American television]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:CBS television specials]] [[Category:Films directed by Sam Jaimes]]

27 September–20 October 2019. | attendance = 2,250,433 (2017) | genre = [[State fair]] | website = [http://www.bigtex.com/ Official website] }} The '''State Fair of Texas''' is an annual [[state fair]] held in [[Dallas]] at historic [[Fair Park]]. The fair has taken place every year since 1886 except for varying periods during World War I and World War II.[http://www.bigtex.com/sft/AboutUs/StateFair.asp Bigtex.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140213232103/http://www.bigtex.com/sft/AboutUs/StateFair.asp |date=2014-02-13 }} It usually begins the last Friday in September and ends 24 days later. While an annual attendance of over 2 million,{{Cite web|url=https://bigtex.com/about-us/daily-attendance/|title=Daily Attendence|last=|first=|date=|website=The State Fair of Texas|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 11, 2018}} it is consistently recognized as one of the most highly attended and best state fairs in America as well as Dallas's signature event.{{cite news| url=https://nypost.com/2014/06/05/americas-best-state-fairs/ | work=New York Post | first1=Sid | last1=Lipsey | first2=Yahoo | last2=Travel | title=The 7 best state fairs in America | date=June 5, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.coca-colacompany.com/stories/5-cant-miss-state-fairs-plus-a-look-at-cokes-refreshing-history-on-the-midway|title=America's 5 Best State Fairs|publisher=|accessdate=26 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chiefads.com/import/texas-fair-downplays-attendance/article_fd381d4f-cd48-5a23-8edc-eb22544f742d.html|title=chieftain.com|first=Pueblo|last=Chieftain|website=Pueblo Chieftain|accessdate=26 August 2017}} ==Attractions== [[File:BigTex-457.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Big Tex]], mascot of the fair since 1952]] The State Fair of Texas opening day ceremonies are highlighted by the annual Friday parade rolling through [[downtown Dallas, Texas|downtown Dallas]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thedallassocials.com/events/state-fair-of-texas-opening-day-parade-2/|title=State Fair of Texas: Opening Day Parade - Dallas Socials|date=25 September 2014|publisher=|accessdate=26 August 2017}} Traditionally, the centerpiece of the fair has been the annual [[college football]] game between [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] and [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]], nicknamed the [[Red River Showdown|Red River Rivalry]] (historically known as both the "OU-Texas Game" or "Texas-OU Game") and played in the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]] at Fair Park. Also, the [[State Fair Classic]], featuring [[Grambling State Tigers football|Grambling State University]] and [[Prairie View A&M Panthers football|Prairie View A&M University]], is played at the Cotton Bowl during the fair. In 2010, [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor]] and [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech]] played their game during the fair for the first time. During the opening weekend of the 2013 fair, [[Army Black Knights football|Army]] and [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs football|Louisiana Tech]] played in the only [[Heart of Dallas Classic]] at the Cotton Bowl; it was abandoned thereafter. The new Texas State Fair Football Showdown is scheduled to take place on the third weekend of the 2018 and 2019 fair and will feature [[Southern Jaguars football|Southern]] and [[Texas Southern Tigers football|Texas Southern]].{{cite web|author=Luke Johnson|date=October 8, 2016|title='This is a major deal:' Southern to play Texas Southern in 2018–19 Texas State Fair Football Showdown|url=http://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/sports/southern/article_fc706b0a-8db6-11e6-8d6a-af44e428f623.html|work=theadvocate.com|accessdate=October 16, 2016}} The State Fair of Texas is the only fair in the US to include a full auto show, dating back to 1913. The State Fair used to feature "Birds of the World" where several birds flew overhead. It was removed from the Fair lineup in 2014. The Texas Skyway is a gondola ride which only operates 24 days a year transports visitors around the fairgrounds. Its construction cost 5 million dollars. There is also a BMX bike show as well as dog and pig races. For children, puppet shows, Children's Medical Center Barnyard, and Story Time also take place inside the fair.{{cite web|title=Official website of The State Fair of Texas|url=http://www.bigtex.com/sft/Entertainment/Attractions.asp}} In recent years, the fair has emphasized its reputation as an event featuring unique, albeit high-fat foods. It has been known for years for Fletcher's brand [[corny dog]]s. Recent years have seen the introduction of new unusual deep-fried items, including deep-fried [[Oreo]]s, deep-fried [[Twinkie]]s, deep-fried [[s'more]]s, deep-fried pork ribs, fried cheesecake; deep-fried butter, fried avocados, deep-fried [[peanut butter]], [[fruit preserves|jelly]], and banana sandwiches, and most recently a batter-based [[fried Coke]]. New foods in 2008 included [[chicken fried bacon]] and fried banana splits. For the 2012 fair, the Girl Scouts of Northeast Texas added the deep-fried Samoa cookie.{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/11/deep-fried-samoa-girl-scout-cookies_n_1664965.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Rachel | last=Tepper | title=Deep-Fried Samoa Girl Scout Cookies Hit The State Fair Circuit | date=July 11, 2012}} ==History== Originally what was known as the State Fair of Texas was held in [[Houston]] from 1870 through 1878.{{cite web |url=https://www.chron.com/heights/news/article/Few-traces-remain-of-state-fair-site-4392244.php |title=Few traces remain of state fair site |author=Meeks, Flori |publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=March 28, 2013 |accessdate=May 22, 2018}} In its modern incarnation, the State Fair of Texas was charted as a private corporation by local businessmen. It was an immediate success and attracted thousands of people. However, in 1904 a series of events led to a financial crisis and not enough income was available to keep the fair running. Therefore, the businessmen sold it to the city of Dallas with the agreement that 24 days during the fall would be set aside annually for the fair and exhibition.Nancy Wiley, "State Fair of Texas", Handbook of Texas Online (http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/lks02), accessed August 16, 2012. Published by the Texas State Historical Association. [[Big Tex]], a {{convert|55|ft|m|adj=on}} tall [[cowboy]] statue, has been its symbol since his introduction in 1952. In 1953, Big Tex's jaw was hinged, so that he appears to "speak" the announcements that promote fair events.Steven Butler. [http://www.watermelon-kid.com/places/FairPark/fp-history/fp-timeline4.htm Fair Park Timeline, part 4: The Post-Exposition Years (1938-1984)] After a fire on October 19, 2012 destroyed the original Big Tex, he was rebuilt and reintroduced for the 2013 fair. Big Tex is claimed to be the world's tallest cowboy.[https://rove.me/to/texas/state-fair-of-texas State Fair of Texas] rove.me Its {{convert|212|ft|m|adj=on}} [[Texas Star]] [[Ferris wheel]] was the largest in North America when it debuted in October 1985, just months before the Texas [[Sesquicentennial]]. It has since been dwarfed by Ferris wheels in Las Vegas and Orlando.[http://www.bigtex.com/sponsors/whatmakesusunique/ "What makes us unique,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913173422/http://www.bigtex.com/sponsors/whatmakesusunique/ |date=2008-09-13 }} BigTex.com. Retrieved 2008-09-24.Norman Anderson. ''Ferris wheels: an illustrated history'', Popular Press, 1992, page 138-40. [[Dallas Area Rapid Transit|DART's]] [[Fair Park Station]] and [[J.B. Jackson, Jr. Transit Center|MLK Jr. Station]] opened in 2009 to serve Fair Park and the State Fair. In addition to regular service on the [[Green Line (Dallas Area Rapid Transit)|Green Line]], the [[Red Line (Dallas Area Rapid Transit)|Red Line]] and [[Blue Line (Dallas Area Rapid Transit)|Blue Line]] also run "special event" trains to Fair Park Station for major fair events.[http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/092309dnmetfairsafety.1a61a692d.html Dallasnews.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926005548/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/092309dnmetfairsafety.1a61a692d.html |date=2009-09-26 }} ===Controversies=== In 1955, [[Juanita Craft#Biography|Juanita Craft]] organized a protest of the State Fair of Texas against its policy of admitting blacks only on "Negro Achievement Day." [https://www.womenintexashistory.org/audio/craft/ Women In Texas History - Juanita Craft] The State Fair in 1966 commissioned a report on the redevelopment of the fair, which concluded that the land around Fair Park should be `bought up and turned into a paved, lighted, fenced parking lot" that would `eliminate the problem from sight'. "If the poor Negroes in their shacks cannot be seen, all the guilt feelings…will disappear, or at least be removed from primary consideration". The State Fair came under fire in October 2014 for spending over $5,000,000 on attorneys fees to two insiders.{{cite web|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2014/10/01/state-fair-of-texas-pays-above-average-legal-bills/|title=State Fair Of Texas Pays 'Above Average' Legal Bills|first=L. P.|last=Phillips|publisher=|accessdate=26 August 2017}} Despite a $30,000,000 investment in Summer Adventures, the event was shuttered after just one season.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/white-rock-east-dallas/headlines/20140218-there-wont-be-summer-adventures-in-fair-park-this-year.ece|title=There won’t be Summer Adventures in Fair Park this year|date=18 February 2014|publisher=|accessdate=26 August 2017}} In August 2015, the State Fair was sanctioned more than $75,000 for filing a SLAPP suit[34] against a lawyer who had requested financial documents from the State Fair. On August 2, 2016, the Dallas Court of Appeals reversed in its entirety the judgment against the State Fair of Texas, holding that the trial court erred in, among other things, finding that the State Fair's lawsuit was a SLAPP suit.{{Cite web|url=http://www.search.txcourts.gov/SearchMedia.aspx?MediaVersionID=2d5dc8b9-6395-4bb7-9dc6-943ff76b575e&MediaID=3c72e1b0-c254-4346-b1cf-ce29adb1a72c&coa=%22%20+%20this.CurrentWebState.CurrentCourt%20+%20@%22&DT=Opinion|title=Dallas Court of Appeals Opinion|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} ===Timeline=== [[File:Texas State Fair at night.jpg|thumb|A glimpse of the State Fair of Texas at night in 2006]] * The State Fair of Texas opened its gates for the first time on October 26, 1886. Approximately 14,000 people attend the opening day. * On November 7, 1886, the fair closes and attracted over 100,000 people for the very first year. * The State Fair of Texas has a history of racial discrimination dating back to the 1880s. The first designated day for African-Americans to attend the fair was held in 1889 and was called "Colored People's Day." Educator Norman Washington Harllee organized exhibits and planned events and speakers including Booker T. Washington in 1900. In 1910, "Colored People's Day" was discontinued and reappeared in 1936 as "Negro Achievement Day" set to coincide with the Texas Centennial Exposition. Contrary to the fact that African-Americans weren’t allowed to participate in entertainment or eat at restaurants and concession stands on other days during the run, fair officials touted "Negro Achievement Day" as a way to recognize the accomplishments and progress of the Negro race in Texas and the United States. The Hall of Negro Life was the only building demolished after the Texas Centennial ended.{{cite web|url=https://dallaslibrary2.org/mbutts/assets/lessons/L12-civil+rights/Marion+Butts+-+State+Fair(PPT).pdf|title=Dallas Public Library - Site Map|website=dallaslibrary2.org|accessdate=26 August 2017}} * In 1913, the fair introduces the first Automobile building which was filled with 175 vehicles for fairgoers to see. * The fair was canceled in 1918 due to the [[US Army]] taking control of Fair Park to establish an aviation boot camp known as Camp Dick. * In 1921, Boston College beats Baylor at the first game ever played between teams from the [[Southwestern United States|southwest]] and [[Northeastern United States|northeast]]. * In 1921, Texas and Vanderbilt start a series which is played here every year from 1921 to 1928 with the exception of 1924. * In 1923, the fair hosted Ku Klux Klan day. Thousands of new Klan members were sworn in at the fairgrounds. More than 150,000 people were at the fair that day.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/state-fair-of-texas/headlines/20111007-fair-flashback-during-the-state-fairs-early-years-many-racial-barriers.ece|title=Everything you need for the State Fair of Texas|website=GuideLive|accessdate=26 August 2017}} * In 1925, the first [[State Fair Classic]] is played. * In 1929, TX-OU play their [[Red River Shootout|Red River Rivalry]] here for the first time. * In 1930, construction of a new Fair Park Stadium (now known as the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]]) begins. * In 1932, TX-OU play their Red River Rivalry for the first time at the new Fair Park Stadium. * In 1937, the first [[Cotton Bowl Classic]] is played in Fair Park. * Big Tex makes his first appearance in 1952. * In 1955, a seat filled with members of the Memphis High School marching band broke free from the top of a 92-foot Sky Wheel, killing a 15-year-old girl.{{cite web|title=Ferris Wheel Seat Plunges Killing Girl|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19551012&id=mGZYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A_gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3852,431186&hl=en|website=www.news.google.com/newspapers|publisher=The Bulletin|accessdate=10 October 2015}} * In 1956 the [[Trailblazer (monorail)|Trailblazer]] monorail began operation at Fair Park from 1956 to 1964. It was the first commercially operated monorail system in the United States.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} * [[Elvis Presley]] performs in the Cotton Bowl during the fair in 1956. [[File:Texas Star - Texas State Fair.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Texas Star]] [[Ferris wheel]] at night]] * In 1960, the [[Dallas Texans (AFL)|Dallas Texans]] ([[American Football League|AFL]]) and the [[Dallas Cowboys]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]) play their first season in the Cotton Bowl. * In 1964 the monorail closed and was replaced by the Swiss Sky Ride, a 64 car aerial ride that traveled over a 3,800 foot path (the longest ever built). * In 1966, the State Fair commissioned a report on the redevelopment of the fair, which concluded that the land around Fair Park should be `bought up and turned into a paved, lighted, fenced parking lot" that would `eliminate the problem from sight'. "If the poor Negroes in their shacks cannot be seen, all the guilt feelings…will disappear, or at least be removed from primary consideration".{{cite web|url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc663026/m1/78/|title=University of North Texas Digital Library, "Fair Park Expansion: A Case Study of Political Bias and Protest in Urban Politics", Davies, Elizabeth Durham. Accessed August 25, 2016.|publisher=|accessdate=26 August 2017}} * In 1979, a Sky Ride accident occurred during the last day of the fair, prompting the removal of the attraction. * In 1983, an eighteen-year-old boy was killed and several bystanders were injured when a gondola fell off the [[Enterprise (ride)]]. * In 1985 the [[Texas Star]] opens as the largest [[ferris wheel]] in North America. * In 1989, The Comet Roller Coaster, a Fair Park landmark since 1947, is torn down. * Following the 2001 [[September 11 attacks]], [[Dallas police]] and State Fair officials announce the implementation of new security measures during the annual event. * In 2005, the Fried Peanut Butter, Jelly and Banana Sandwich is introduced to the fair. Went Down to Georgia ==Economics, finances and management== The economics, finances and management of the State Fair of Texas is a matter of public concern and study. The five main areas of concern are: * What is the annual attendance of the fair? * What economic impact does the fair have on people and businesses in the surrounding area? * How much money does the State Fair provide for the benefit of improvements at [[Fair Park]] and elsewhere * State fair staff compensation levels * Audits ===Attendance=== Staff of the State Fair have traditionally reported that attendance at the fair runs in the vicinity each year of between 3 and 3.5 million people. These figures were disputed in an April 2016 study published by Tom Kelly, Ph.D, a professor of Economics at [[Baylor University]] and the Director of Baylor University Center for Business and Economic Research, along with Bennet Hickok, an Economics student at Baylor. The Kelly/Hickok report argues that the attendance at the fair is about 1.5-1.7 million visitors a year, or about half of what state fair staff reported it to be.{{cite news|last1=Kelly|first1=Tom|last2=Hickok|first2=Bennet|title=Reassessing the Economic Impact of Fair Park and the State Fair|url=http://www.baylor.edu/business/economic_research/doc.php/262623.pdf|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=Baylor University|date=April 2016}} According to the 2017 State Fair of Texas Annual Report,[https://bigtex.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/9910_AnnualReport_2017_Reduced.pdf 2017 State Fair of Texas Annual Report] Retrieved Jul 15, 2018 the Fair attracted a total of 2,250,433 attendees during the 2017 event with roughly 93,000 daily guests. ===Economic impact on surrounding businesses=== The 2016 Kelly/Hickok study found that the State Fair generates around $50 million for the area economy. This is in contrast to the figure of $600 million in impact that the State Fair itself has traditionally reported.{{cite news|last1=Shipp|first1=Brett|title=Economist's study raises eyebrows about State Fair's future in Fair Park|url=http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/dallas-county/economists-study-raises-eyebrows-about-state-fairs-future-in-fair-park/171813101|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=WFAA|date=May 4, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Steve|title=How valuable is Big Tex to Dallas? State Fair's fuzzy numbers make it hard to tell|url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2016/04/how-valuable-is-big-tex-to-dallas-state-fairs-fuzzy-numbers-make-it-hard-to-tell.html/|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=The Dallas Morning News|date=April 15, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Steve|title=Big Tex's economic impact? Try $50 million, says new study on the State Fair|url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2016/04/big-texs-economic-impact-try-50-million-says-new-study-on-the-state-fair.html/|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=The Dallas Morning News|date=April 19, 2016}} ===How excess revenue is spent=== The State Fair has a lease with [[Fair Park]], the terms of which require that any profit or excess revenue it generates be spent "for the development and enhancement of Fair Park and the Fair". In May 2016, the State Fair released a list of capital projects for the past 10 years, detailing how the fair had spent their excess revenue. According to media reports, 90% of excess revenue was spent on projects that solely benefited the State Fair. A survey of [[Fair Park]] revealed out of the 277 acres available, 200 are covered in asphalt or concrete, compared to 10 acres of green space.{{cite news|last1=Wilonsky|first1=Robert|title=Dallas isn’t keeping a close eye on Big Tex and city's other Fair Park partners, says audit|url=http://cityhallblog.dallasnews.com/2016/05/dallas-isnt-keeping-a-close-eye-on-big-tex-and-citys-other-fair-park-partners-says-audit.html/|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=The Dallas Morning News|date=May 13, 2016}} ===Staff compensation=== In 2014, Errol McKoy, the former President of the State Fair of Texas, received $1.425 million in compensation.{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Steve|title=Big Tex tries to be more transparent about State Fair spending|url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2016/04/big-tex-tries-to-be-more-transparent-about-state-fair-spending.html/|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=The Dallas Morning News|date=April 22, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Cassidy|first1=Jon|title=State Fair's expenses help explain Fair Park's blight|url=http://watchdog.org/263984/fair-expenses-park/|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=Watchdog.org|date=May 2, 2016}}{{cite web|title=STATE FAIR OF TEXAS|url=http://www.eri-nonprofit-salaries.com/?FuseAction=NPO.Summary&EIN=756002511&BMF=1&Cobrandid=0&Syndicate=No|publisher=Economic Research Institute|accessdate=27 July 2016}} ===Audits=== On May 13, 2016, the City of Dallas Auditor, Craig Kinton, released an audit regarding Fair Park Business Partners, which included the State Fair of Texas. The audit concluded the City of Dallas had no way to ensure the State Fair was adequately investing in [[Fair Park]], per the terms of the contract between the City of Dallas and State Fair.{{cite news|last1=Kinton|first1=Craig|title=AUDIT OF FAIR PARK BUSINESS PARTNERS OVERSIGHT|url=http://dallascityhall.com/departments/auditor/DCH%20Documents/Audit%20and%20Attestation%20Reports%20FY%202016%20(10-01-2015%20to%2009-30-2016)/A16-009%20-%20Audit%20of%20Fair%20Park%20Business%20Partners%20Oversight%2005-13-2016.pdf|accessdate=27 July 2016|publisher=Office of the Dallas, Texas City Auditor|date=May 13, 2016}} ==See also== {{Portal|Texas}} * [[A Fair To Remember (documentary)]] * [[Fair Park]] * [[Hall of State]] * [[Heart of Dallas Classic]] * [[State Fair Classic]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Texas State Fair}} * {{official|http://www.bigtex.com}} *{{Handbook of Texas|id=lks02|name=State Fair of Texas}} *[http://www.pegasusnews.com/places/state-fair-texas/ Local guide to State Fair of Texas events] *[http://neighborsgo.com/photos/search/State%20Fair Neighborsgo.com: Photos submitted by Fairgoers] {{State agencies of Texas}} {{Dallas}} {{DEFAULTSORT:State Fair Of Texas}} [[Category:State Fair of Texas|*]] [[Category:Fairs in Texas]] [[Category:Fair Park]] [[Category:Festivals in Dallas]] [[Category:State fairs|Texas]] [[Category:Annual events in Texas]] [[Category:Annual fairs]] [[Category:September events]] [[Category:October events]] [[Category:Culture of Dallas]] [[Category:Texas culture]] [[Category:State agencies of Texas]] [[Category:Festivals established in 1886]] [[Category:1886 establishments in Texas]]

[[File:Fireworks at the First Tailteann Games August 15, 1924.jpg|thumb|Fireworks at the first Games, August 15, 1924]] The '''Tailteann Games''' or '''Aonach Tailteann''' was an Irish sporting and cultural festival held in the [[Irish Free State]] in 1924, 1928, and 1932. It was intended as a modern revival of the [[Tailteann Games (ancient)|Tailteann Games]] held from legendary times until the [[Norman invasion of Ireland]]; as such it drew inspiration from the [[Modern Olympics]] revival of the [[Ancient Olympics]]. [[Croke Park]], the Dublin headquarters of the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]], was the venue for the opening ceremony and many of the sports events, which were open to people of [[Irish people|Irish]] birth or ancestry. The Tailteann Games were held shortly after the Summer Olympics, such that athletes participating in [[1924 Summer Olympics|Paris 1924]] and [[1928 Summer Olympics|Amsterdam 1928]] came to compete. Participants coming from England, Scotland, Wales, Canada, the USA, South Africa and Australia as well as Ireland.<ref name="HoganstandCPHist">[http://www.hoganstand.com/general/ground/articles/0328033.htm History of Croke Park - Hogan Stand] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221041915/http://www.hoganstand.com/general/ground/articles/0328033.htm |date=2007-02-21 }}</ref> [[Chess]] competitions were held in conjunction with the [[Irish Chess Union]] as part of the Tailteann Games. There were also artistic competitions and industrial displays. The games became regarded as a [[Cumann na nGaedheal]] project, and when that party lost power to [[Fianna Fáil]] after the [[Irish general election, 1932|1932 election]] there was no financial backing for further games.<ref>Cronin 2005, p.64</ref>
==Origins== This revival "meeting of the Irish race" was announced by [[Éamon de Valera]] in Dáil Éireann in 1921. The [[1922 Irish Race Convention]] supported the plan for an "Irish Race Olympic".<ref>Dean 2014 p.91</ref> However, due to the [[Anglo-Irish War]] and [[Irish Civil War|Civil War]] it was not held until 1924.<ref>[http://goireland.about.com/od/historyculture/qt/gg_tailteann.htm The Tailteann Games - An Olympic Event for the "Celtic Race"], by Bernd Biege, About.com</ref> The meeting was launched to celebrate the independence of Ireland. The [[Hogan Stand]] was built and opened for the 1924 games.<ref name="HoganstandCPHist" />
A report to revive the games was debated in the Dáil in June 1922. Modern sports such as [[motorcycle racing|motorcycling]] and [[shooting sport|shooting]] were to be included, along with a parade of massed choirs. The possibility of out-doing the [[Olympic Games]] was mentioned: "We have got representations from America to the effect that it would be advisable to depart from the idea of confining the Tailteann games to the Irish race and seeing that they predated the Greek Olympic by a thousand years we should be justified in entering upon a more varied programme."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/DT/D.S.192206080008.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121031123831/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/DT/D.S.192206080008.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-10-31|title=Dil ireann - Volume 2 - 08 June, 1922 - IOMATHOIRI IASACHTA.|work=oireachtas.ie}}</ref> The games were delayed by the [[Irish Civil War]] of 1922–23.
==Symbols== [[Commemorative medal]]s were struck for all three games, in gold, silver, silver gilt, and bronze. They depict [[Tailtiu]], the patron deity of the ancient Tailteann Games, with inscription "An Bhainrioghan Tailte" ("Queen Tailte").<ref>{{cite journal|last=Went|first=Arthur E. J.|date=June 1978|title=Medallic Illustrations of Dublin History|journal=Dublin Historical Record|publisher=Old Dublin Society|volume=31|issue=3|pages=97–104 : 103 |jstor=30104073}}</ref>
==1924== The games opened with the "Tailteann choir" singing the "Tailteann ode", with words by [[Oliver St. John Gogarty]] and music by Louis O'Brien.<ref name="McAsey">{{cite journal|last=McAsey|first=Carmel C. |jstor=30087165|date=December 1969|title=Dubliners and Opera|journal=Dublin Historical Record|publisher=Old Dublin Society|volume=23|issue=2/3|pages=45–55 : 53}} ; {{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000513987 |title=Aonach tailteann 1924 prize ode |last1=Gogarty |first1=Oliver St. John |last2=O'Brien |first2=Louis |year=1924 |work=Holdings |publisher=Piggott |accessdate=1 August 2017 |location=Dublin}}</ref> The ode won Gogarty a bronze medal in the literature section of the [[Art competitions at the 1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Olympic art competition]]. The [[Irish flag]] was carried by [[Tom Kiely]], winner of the [[Athletics at the 1904 Summer Olympics – Men's all-around|1904 Olympic all-around (decathlon)]] title.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zarnowski|first=Frank|date=August 2006|title=Thomas F. Kiely: A biography|journal=Journal of Olympic History|volume=14|issue=2|pages=5–11: 11|url=http://library.la84.org/SportsLibrary/JOH/JOHv14n2/JOHv14n2f.pdf#page=6 |format=PDF}}</ref>
To increase the quality of the competition, some Olympic stars without Irish heritage were invited to compete as guests.<ref name="Rouse2017">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/columnists/paul-rouse/when-irelands-tailteann-games-eclipsed-the-olympics-431134.html|title=When Ireland’s Tailteann Games eclipsed the Olympics|last=Rouse|first=Paul|date=18 November 2016|work=Irish Examiner|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
The [[Irish republican legitimism|dissident Irish republican government]] which had lost the Civil War urged a boycott of the games "falsely described as Aonach Tailteann", because it rejected the legitimacy of the Free State government which sponsored the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000507179|title=To the people of Ireland and to every member of the Irish race|last=Ruttledge|first=P. J. |authorlink=P. J. Ruttledge |year=1924|work=Holdings|publisher=National Library of Ireland|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> [[Rugby union]] was excluded from the program because the [[Irish Rugby Football Union]] was seen as "undemocratic and almost un-Irish".<ref>Rouse 2015 p.269</ref>
===Chess=== Run in conjunction with the [[Irish Chess Union]], there were three competitions, the overall competition was won by the reigning Irish Champion [[Philip Baker (chess player)|Philip Baker]], the Major Competition was won by [[Lord Dunsany]], with Aaron Sayers as runner-up.<ref>[https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/columnists/paul-rouse/when-irelands-tailteann-games-eclipsed-the-olympics-431134.html When Irelands Tailteann Games eclipsed the Olympics] by Paul Rouse, Irish Examiner, November 18, 2016.</ref> Dublin Chess Club provided its premises and equipment for use for the Competitions.<ref>'A History of Dublin Chess Club' by A. A. Luce, 1967.</ref>
===Hurling=== In [[hurling]], teams from England, Wales, the United States, Scotland, and Ireland played.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Leeworthy|first=Daryl|year=2012|title=The Forgotten Hurlers of South Wales: Sport, Society and the Irish, 1910–1925|journal=Journal of Welsh People's History|publisher=[[Llafur]]|volume=11|issue=2|issn=0306-0837|url=http://eprints.hud.ac.uk/id/eprint/18278/}}</ref>
A [[shinty–hurling]] match was played between Scotland team organised by the [[Camanachd Association]] and an Ireland team organised by the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] (GAA).
The [[Camogie Association]] planned national and international [[camogie]] competitions, but withdrew after a dispute with the organisers, reflecting the anti-Free State bias of the association's leadership. An exhibition match was played without the association's sanction,<ref name="NicCongail2013">{{cite journal|last=Nic Congáil|first=Ríona|date=Spring–Summer 2013|title="Looking on for Centuries from the Sideline": Gaelic Feminism and the Rise of Camogie|journal=Éire-Ireland :|volume=48|issue=1 & 2|pages=168–190 : 184|url=http://doras.dcu.ie/21567/1/117_SCAN.pdf#page=17 |format=PDF}}</ref> while an association "Ireland" team played in London.
===Swimming=== Swimming events were held in the pond at [[Dublin Zoo]].<ref name="Rouse2017" /> American [[Johnny Weissmuller]] and Australian [[Boy Charlton|Andrew "Boy" Charleton]] took part.<ref name="Rouse2017" />
===Athletics=== The American [[Harold Osborn]], the [[Athletics at the 1924 Summer Olympics – Men's high jump|1924 Olympic high jump]] champion, won the same event in the Tailteann Games
===Sailing=== The Sailing events of 1924 were sailed in Kingstown (now [[Dún Laoghaire]]) on Saturday in the second week of August.
{|class="wikitable" |+Tailteann Games 1924 sailing events<ref>{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000553002|title=Aonach Tailteann : programme of sailing.|work=Holdings|publisher=[[National Library of Ireland]]|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> |- ! Race !! Class !! Result |- | 1 || Yachts over 10 tons || 'Mavourneen', Mr. F. St. J. Worrall.<ref> Irish Times 11 Aug. 1924 </ref> |- | 2 || 25 ft & [[Dublin Bay 21|21 ft]] || 'Geraldine', Mr. W. McDowell. |- | 3 || Yachts up to 10 tons || 'Klysma', Mr. C. O'Loughlin. |- | 4 || 17 ft || 'Echo', Mr. R. Hall. |- | 5 || [[Seapoint]] [Sailing Club] No. 2 & [[Clontarf, Dublin|Clontarf]] [Yacht & Boat Club] class || 'Falcon', Messrs. Hutchinson and Paine. |- | 6 || [[Shannon-One-Design]] || 1 S47 Edgar H. Waller ; 2 S32 N. Lionel Lyster ; 3 S35 A.G. Waller ; 4 S36 R. White ; 5 S34 Walter Levinge ; 6 S45 Tom Feely ; 7 S43 Jocelyn H. de W. Waller |- | 7 || [[Water Wag]]s || 'Coquette', Mr. G.H. Jones. |}
===Motor Boating=== The Motor Boat event of 1924 took place in [[Dublin Bay]].
===Cultural programme=== [[File:Tailteann Games Visitors at the R.I.A. 1924 (18426438103).jpg|thumb|Irish and foreign dignitaries at the RIA]] [[W. B. Yeats]] persuaded the [[Royal Irish Academy]] to award prizes. The gold medal went to [[Stephen MacKenna]] for his translation of [[Plotinus]]; other winners were Oliver Gogarty, [[Francis Stuart]], and [[James Stephens (author)|James Stephens]]. A banquet presided over by [[T. M. Healy]], the [[Governor-General of the Irish Free State]], had an "oddly assorted" group of guests invited by Yeats, including [[Augustus John]], Sir [[Edwin Lutyens]], writers [[Compton Mackenzie]], [[G. K. Chesterton]], [[Lennox Robinson]], and [[Carlos Magalhães de Azeredo]]; cricketers [[Ranjitsinhji]] and [[C. B. Fry]]; and diplomats [[Willem Hubert Nolens]] and [[Erik Palmstierna]]. Chesterton accepted the medal on his behalf of the absent MacKenna, who later refused it.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hone |first=Joseph |title=W. B. Yeats |chapter=Meditations in Time of Civil War; 7. |chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.182548/2015.182548.Wb-Yeats#page/n374 |year=1963 |pages=362–365 |origyear=1943 |publisher=Macmillan }}</ref>
An art and craft exhibition at the [[Royal Hibernian Academy]] displayed 1,597 works, more than half entered for competition in 32 categories.<ref>Cronin 2005, pp.64–65</ref> The overall "Tailteann Trophy" went to [[Seán Keating]]'s ''Homage to Hugh Lane''.<ref name="cronin2015p65">Cronin 2005, p.65</ref> Other gold medallists included [[Margaret Clarke (artist)|Margaret Clarke]], [[Francis Doyle Jones]], [[Letitia Hamilton]], [[Power O'Malley]], and [[Patrick Tuohy]].<ref name="cronin2015p65"/>
At the [[Theatre Royal, Dublin|Theatre Royal]] two recent operas by Irish composers were performed: [[Geoffrey Molyneux Palmer]]'s ''Sruth na Maoile'' (1922) and Harold White's ''Seán the Post'' (1924), along with ''Shamus O'Brien'' (1896) by [[Charles Villiers Stanford|Charles V. Stanford]].<ref name="McAsey" /> The last was not successful: "there seemed to be a greater number of people in the orchestra than in the audience".<ref>Joseph O'Neill: "Music in Dublin", in: ''Music in Ireland. A Symposium'', ed. by Aloys Fleischmann (Cork: Cork University Press, 1952), p. 255.</ref>
In the [[genre painting]] competition, Charles Lamb won a silver medal for ''Dancing at a Northern Crossroads'', depicting a traditional [[crossroads dance]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bourke|first=Marie|date=Spring 2000|title=A Growing Sense of National Identity|journal=History Ireland|volume=8|issue=1|url=http://www.historyireland.com/20th-century-contemporary-history/a-growing-sense-of-national-identity/}}</ref>
==1928== The programme for the 1928 games included athletics, [[billiards]], [[boxing]], camogie, chess, cycling, Gaelic football, [[golf]], [[gymnastics]], [[Gaelic handball]], hurling, [[Motorcycle racing|motorcycling]], [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]], and [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000510731|title=Aonach Tailteann|author=Committee of Aonach Tailteann and Irish Tourist Information|year=1928|work=Holdings|publisher=National Library of Ireland|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
At the awards ceremony in the [[Iveagh Gardens]], the [[Medieval pageant|pageant]] ''The Coming of Fionn'' by Seamus MacCall was staged.<ref>Dean 2014 p.95</ref>
===Chess=== The 1928 Games was won by [[John O'Hanlon (chess player)|John O'Hanlon]] a multiple Irish Champion.
===Motor Boating=== The Motor Boat event of 1928 took place at [[Ballyglass]], Co. Westmeath, home of the Lough Ree Yacht Club, and Motor Yacht Club of Ireland, on 16 August. Races took place in various classes: *Race 1. Free for all sweepstakes. 1st. 'Fiend' J.W. Shillan. 2nd. 'Irish Express' Major H. Waller. 3rd. 'Miss Chief' J. C. Healy. *Race 2. Handicap for boats with outboard engines not exceeding 350cc. Boat min. weight 120 lbs. 1st. 'Miss Chief' J.C. Healy. 2nd. 'Busy Bee' Lt. Col. Mansfield. 3rd. 'Imp' D. Tidmarsh. *Race 3. Handicap for boats with inboard engines exceeding 20'-0". 1st. 'Shrike' Lt. Col. Mansfield. 2nd.'La Vague' Dr. V. S. Delany. 3rd. 'Janet' J. C. Healy. *Race 4. Handicap for boats with outboard engines of unlimited cc. Boat min. weight 140 lbs. 1st. 'Baby Costume' L. Hogan. 2nd.'Fiend' J. W. Shillan. 3rd. 'Busy Bee' Lt. Col. Mansfield. *Race 5. Free for all scratch race. Outboard engines. 1st. 'Fiend' J. W. Shillan. 2nd. 'Miss Chief' J. C. Healy. 3rd. 'Busy Bee' Lt. Col. Mansfield. *Race 6. Handicap race for boats with inboard engines, length not exceeding 20 ft. 1st. 'Udra' Dr. V.S. Delany. 2nd. 'Mermaid' Mr. J. Ryan.
==1932== With the [[1932 Summer Olympics]] begin held in Los Angeles, the Tailteann Games was originally scheduled for 1931 to avoid a clash, but postponed to 1932, which meant Olympic athletes from Ireland or abroad could not be present. The Games' main backer, minister [[J. J. Walsh]], lost office when [[Government of the 7th Dáil|Fianna Fáil took power]] after the [[Irish general election, 1932|1932 election]], and public funding was cut. Against a background of the [[Great Depression]] and the [[Anglo-Irish Trade War]], the Games cut from two weeks to one; they made a £12 profit.
===Chess=== The third games was won again by [[John O'Hanlon (chess player)|John O'Hanlon]] who was also Irish Champion in 1932.
===Sailing=== The sailing events were hosted by the [[National Yacht Club]], Dun Laoghaire in July 1932.<ref name="it19320711">{{cite newspaper |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=11 July 1932}}</ref> {|class="wikitable" |- ! Event !! Result |- | Cruisers under 10 tons<ref name="it19320711"/> || ''Mercia III'', W. J. Smalldridge (5h 22m 31s); ''Sho Shi'', T.A. Cotter (5:31:15); ''Eileen'', J.A. Magauran (5:39:35) (Winner); ''Alethea'', J. Kelly. |- | 21-footers<ref name="it19320711"/> || ''Maureen'' (winner) Newsom & Stephens; ''Geraldine'', W McDowell; ''Oola'', F.E. Bitmingham; ''Innisfallen'', J.T. Wigham. |- | 17-footers<ref name="it19320711"/> || ''Pauline'', Dr. H.J. Wright; ''Zaida'', Dr. H.H. Poole; ''Rita'', Mr. A. O'Reilly; ''Mimosa'', Mr. R.N. Guinness; ''Bobolink'', Mr. A. McMullen; ''Leila'', Mr. W. McBride; ''Hera'', Mr. A.E. Nesbitt; ''Echo'', Mr. R. Hall; ''Anita'', Mr. J. Millar; ''Oona'', Dr. D & Miss Douglas; ''Deilginis'', Capt. O'B. Twohig; ''Rosemay'', Messrs. Sterling & Thompson; ''Silver Moon'' (carried away her masthead before the preparatory gun). |- | Water wags<ref name="it19320711"/> || ''Pansy'', Dr. J. H. Stephens; ''Phyllis'', G.A. Newsom; ''Coquette'', George Jones; ''Tomboy'', Mr. &. Mrs. Donolly; ''Mollie'', Dr & Mrs Henry; ''Blue Bird'', Dr. G. Pugin; ''Amyl'', Mr. & Mrs. Shackleton; ''Nesta'', A.W. Bayne; ''Marie Louise'', E.G. Peake; ''Cupid'', S. S. Harman; ''Alfa'', G.D. Findlater; ''Kittiwake'', E.A. Brittain (fouled mark); ''Mary Kate'', A.R. O'Connor (retired). |}
==1937== In 1937 [[Éamon de Valera]] organised an inter-[[Department of State (Ireland)|departmental]] committee into the feasibility of staging another games, which reported in June that it would be possible to stage one in 1939. De Valera used the [[National Athletic and Cycling Association#Splits and isolation|split in Irish athletics governance]] as an excuse to defer consideration, to the chagrin of J. J. Walsh. The onset of the [[Second World War]] deferred any progress and nothing further happened after the war.<ref>Rouse 2015 p.255</ref>

{{Infobox Convention | name = Tomo-Dachi | logo = Tomo-dachi con.JPG|logo_size=230px | caption = Tomo-Dachi logo | status = Defunct | venue = [[Magee College]] | location = Derry, Northern Ireland | country = | first = 2005 | last = 2007 | attendance = 200+ in 2006 | activity = Video Rooms, Cosplay Catwalk, Cosplay Theatre, Disco, Dealer's Room, Panels, Video Game Rooms, Artist's Alley, Manga Rooms, and Karaoke. }}
'''Tomo-Dachi''' was an [[anime convention]] based in [[Derry]], [[Northern Ireland]].<ref name="ulster2005">{{cite press release | url = http://news.ulster.ac.uk/releases/2005/1976.html | title = Magee To Host Japanese Animation Convention | date = 2005-12-07 | accessdate = 2007-02-05 | publisher = [[University of Ulster]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061015035202/http://news.ulster.ac.uk/releases/2005/1976.html | archivedate = 2006-10-15 | df = }}</ref>
Starting in the summer of 2005, Tomo-Dachi was the first [[anime]] convention to run in [[Ireland]].<ref name="irishsf">{{cite web | url = http://www.slovobooks.com/irishsfnews/news.php?postid=235 | title=Anime Con for Northern Ireland | date = 2005-08-22 | accessdate = 2007-02-05 | publisher = Irish Sci-Fi News}}</ref>
The original venue was [[Nerve Centre|The Nerve Centre]], on Magazine Street in the city centre of [[Derry]]. Tomo-Dachi, also known as TDXX (the "XX" is replaced by the year - such as TD05, TD06, etc.) is now held annually at the [[Magee College]] of the [[University of Ulster]].<ref name="ulster2005"/>
The name of the event comes from the word {{nihongo|''tomodachi''|友達|}}, which means "friends"<!---since it's a conference, I'm assuming the plural version is implied---> in [[Japanese language|Japanese]].
==History== In 2004 when the original Tomo-dachi committee was formed there had never been an anime convention held anywhere in Ireland, north or south of the border. The announcement and run up to the first outing of the anime convention was reported in multiple local and national based papers including the [[Belfast Telegraph]], [[The News Letter]] and the [[Daily Ireland]].
==Tomo-Dachi 2005== Tomo-Dachi 2005 (or TD05 for short) was held in August 2005.<ref name="AC2005">{{cite web | url = https://animecons.com/events/info/962/tomo-dachi-2005 | title = Tomo-Dachi 2005 Information | work = AnimeCons.com | accessdate = 2006-10-04}}</ref> It was the first anime convention to be held on the Island of Ireland, and was operated and run by DAMA, the Derry Anime and Manga Association. The one-day event attracted 83 people.
===Location & Details=== TD05 took place at the [[Nerve Centre]], a public entertainment venue in Derry based in the city centre, and the convention made use of its unique facilities. This was venue where the Derry Anime and Manga Association held their meetings.
The one-day convention was made up of multiple areas. One screening room, that being an actual [[movie theatre|cinema]].
The event also held Northern Ireland's first Anime Convention Cosplay Contest, which was won by Ryan McDermott.
==Tomo-Dachi 2006== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:tomo06.jpg|right|thumb|TOMO-DACHI 2006]] -->The plans for the following year's event included a change of venue and lengthening Tomo-Dachi into a three days event.
The convention took place on the weekend of July 7, 2006.<ref name="AC2006">{{cite web | url = https://animecons.com/events/info/968/tomo-dachi-2006 | title = Tomo-Dachi 2006 Information | work = AnimeCons.com | accessdate = 2006-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Una | last = Bradley | url = http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/incoming/article1849041.ece | title = Manga from heaven | work = Belfast Telegraph | publisher = Independent News & Media | date = 2006-07-07 | accessdate = 2007-02-09}}</ref>
===Guests=== The convention was attended by several guests, most notably Ms [[Tiffany Grant]] and Mr [[Matt Greenfield]] in their first ever convention visit in Europe. They were joined by [[Hugh David ADV|Hugh David]] of [[ADV Films|ADV]] films UK, [[Sonia Leong]] and [[Emma Vieceli]] both of [[Sweatdrop Studios|Sweatdrop Manga Studios]].<ref>{{cite press release | url = http://www.anime-ni.co.uk/?p=402 | title = TOMO-DACHI: The Final Press Release | publisher = Tomo-Dachi | date = 2006-06-30 | accessdate = 2006-10-27}}</ref>
===Location & Details=== TD06 was held at [[Magee College]], part of the [[University of Ulster]]. The campus was fully renovated prior to the event,<ref>{{cite press release | url = http://news.ulster.ac.uk/releases/2000/189.html | title = University details £10m Magee College campus expansion | publisher = University of Ulster | date = 2000-03-03 | accessdate = 2006-10-04}}</ref> With classrooms converted into gaming rooms, screening rooms, an artists alley and a Manga library.
TD06 was a three-day convention and offered special events, panels, industry information, dealers and more. Over the weekend it was attended by just over 200 people from Ireland and the United Kingdom.<ref name="TD06_nums">{{cite press release | url = http://www.animeuknews.net/viewpress.php?showarticle=109 | title = Tomo-Dachi committee announces TD07 | date = 2005-09-26 | accessdate = 2007-02-23 | publisher = AnimeUKnews }}</ref>
==Tomo-Dachi 2007== Tomo-Dachi 2007 was held on the weekend starting August 24.<ref name="AC2007">{{cite web | url = https://animecons.com/events/info/1150/tomo-dachi-2007 | title = Tomo-Dachi 2007 Information | work = AnimeCons.com | accessdate = 2018-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release | url = http://www.animeuknews.net/viewpress.php?showarticle=109 | title = The Tomo-Dachi committee announce Tomo-Dachi 2007 | publisher = Tomo-Dachi | date = 2006-08-14 | accessdate = 2006-12-04}}</ref>
The first guest announced for the convention was Guest of Honour [[Mike McFarland]], voice actor and director for [[FUNimation Entertainment]].<ref>{{cite press release | url = http://www.anime-ni.co.uk/?p=584 | title = Tomo-Dachi set to bring Mike McFarland to the UK as pre-registration opens | publisher = Tomo-Dachi | date = 2007-02-06 | accessdate = }}</ref> Other guests include [[Stuart Claw]] and [[Emma Vieceli]] hosts of the UK's [[Anime Network]], [[Sonia Leong]], Manga artist and [[Hugh David (ADV)|Hugh David]] representative of [[ADV Films]].<ref>{{cite press release | url = http://www.animeuknews.net/press/20/tomodachi-announces-more-guests-as-the-closing-of-preregistrations-draws-near | title = Tomo-Dachi announces more guests | publisher = Tomo-Dachi | date = 2007-07-26 | accessdate = }}</ref>

(Poker Aces) |promotion=[[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] |date=July 5, 2002{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#x-b| title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = 2009-02-19| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}} |attendance= |venue=Convention Center |city=Madero, Mexico |lastevent=[[Rey de Reyes (2002)]] |nextevent = [[Verano de Escándalo (2002)]] |event=[[Triplemanía]] |lastevent2=[[Triplemanía IX]] |nextevent2=[[Triplemanía XI]] }} '''Triplemanía X''' was the tenth [[Triplemanía]] [[professional wrestling]] show promoted by [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]]. The show took place on July 5, 2002 in Madero, Mexico. The Main event featured a ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'' match where each wrestler defended the hair of a referee. The participants in this match were [[Heavy Metal (wrestler)|Heavy Metal]], [[Sangre Chicana]], [[El Oriental]], [[Electroshock (wrestler)|Electroshock]], May Flowers and [[El Brazo]]. ==Production== ===Background=== In early 1992 [[Antonio Peña]] was working as a booker and storyline writer for [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL), Mexico's largest and the world's oldest wrestling promotion, and was frustrated by CMLL's very conservative approach to ''[[lucha libre]]''. He joined forced with a number of younger, very talented wrestlers who felt like CMLL was not giving them the recognition they deserved and decided to split from CMLL to create [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]], later known simply as "AAA" or Triple A. After making a deal with the ''Televisa'' television network AAA held their first show in April 1992.{{cite web | url= http://superluchas.net/2006/10/07/el-fin-de-una-era/| title= El fin de una era| date= October 7, 2006 | accessdate= October 14, 2009 | author= Ocampo, Ernesto | publisher= ''SuperLuchas'' Magazine | language=Spanish}} The following year Peña and AAA held their first [[Triplemanía]] event, building it into an annual event that would become AAA's [[Super Bowl]] event, similar to the [[WWE]]'s [[WrestleMania]] being the biggest show of the year.{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre and honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=A family affair|pages=128–132|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}} The 2002 Triplemanía was the 10th year in a row AAA held a Triplemanía show and the fifteenth overall show under the Triplemanía banner. ===Storylines=== The Triplemanía show featured eight [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches. ==Results== {{Pro Wrestling results table |results={{cite news|title=2002: considerar detrás|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|id=Issue 2593|date=January 19, 2003|language=Spanish}} |match1=[[Dos Caras Jr.]], [[Esther Moreno]], [[Pimpinela Escarlata]] and [[Mascarita Dorada|Mascarita Sagrada]] defeated [[Mini Abismo Negro]], Shoot Fighting, Sexy Piscis and [[Tiffany (luchadora)|Tiffany]] |stip1=''[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|Relevos Atómicos de Locura]]'' match |time1= |match2= [[El Oriental]] defeated [[Sangre Chicana]]
